reviewText:
Of the Sands of Time trilogy, Warrior Within is easily the most controversial of the bunch. Forgoing the whimsical Nights of Arabia theme of the much beloved Sands of Time, Warrior Within employs a much darker tone, replacing melodic instrumentals with blood pumping metal music, and an emperor’s majestic castle with that of some dreadful thing from a metal album cover. Gone, too, is the storybook hero known only as the Prince, who is now a curse spewing, murder loving psychopath, easy to anger and eager to slice open stomachs. Understandably, not all took a liking to the new Prince of Persia, and many either wrote it off or gave up after dying in the first 10 minutes, all while cursing the monsters at Ubisoft who would dare slight their beloved franchise so vehemently. I am ashamed to admit that while I did not join in the publisher bashing those many years prior, I did assume the many fans’ angers as legitimate. After having neglected the franchise for many years since the original, I have finally played through the trilogy’s entirety. Lo and behold, my judgment is thus: Warrior Within is the best of the Prince of Persia trilogy, and one of the most challenging and equally frustrating and rewarding titles I have ever had the pleasure of besting.

Where its predecessor, The Sands of Time, relied on linear level progression, a typically gradually increasing difficulty, and relatively basic (and easy) combat, Warrior Within features a (sort of) open world, varied weapons of combat, and enemies that will break your face if you’re not perfect. It also features a higher emphasis on combat than its predecessor, and some of the most frustrating puzzle and enemy design than any other game I’ve played in years. But understand what I mean by that. Warrior Within, for the entire duration, never held my hand. The moment I felt I had a handle on how to deal with an enemy type, a brand new exploding, near unavoidable dog animal thing would be introduced. Obviously, it wasn’t always an exploding dog thing, but you get the point. WW is never easy or gradual in its difficulty. It’s not typically fair, either, but it also never felt impossible, and that’s what made it fantastic. For comparison, while playing Demon’s Souls, I always felt in control of what I was doing, and typically only died if I was quick to run into a room before checking for barriers to hide behind, traps or tricky enemies in the shadows. WW will put you in a room and deal death unto you until you learn to deal with it, and the experience became infinitely rewarding upon besting said situations.

Puzzles don’t quite follow the same degree of difficulty that the combat does, but the challenge comes in unintended traversal. By puzzles, I refer to the Prince of Persia’s method of travel; running along walls, sliding down ropes and hanging banners, and avoiding the many, many spikes and saw blades inexplicably sticking out of walls. The open world aspect of Warrior Within allows you to re-visit any portion of the island that you’ve previously visited, and you don’t necessarily have to follow the same paths. However, the design of these pathways are sometimes altered by the game’s events, and even when they aren’t, traversal in any way different from the standard is a challenge in and of itself, as the developers clearly did not design these paths to be easily followed backwards (or forwards, for that matter), as you will have to do. Worse yet, enemy spawns remain, especially those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dogs I mentioned previously, the ones that can take half of your health. If this sounds frustrating to you, it should. But by the point you should even be considering doing anything like this, you will have already become invested in beating down this seemingly personal hell that the developers have created just for you.

I won’t divulge any of my secrets for passing through Warrior Within, and quite frankly, I would recommend any and all to refrain from guides as much as possible throughout (except for the collectibles, you’ll need a guide for those). Warrior Within is a truly brutal and often unfair achievement in sadistic game design. It’s also one of my most satisfying completions in the entirety of my gaming career. Nearly every instance of combat in this title will chew on your face and kick you in your ♥♥♥ until you really learn to play it. The learning curve can be steep and unfair, and you will want to quit. Don’t. There are no tricks to Warrior Within, and only your skill, and hopefully a share of dumb luck, will see you succeed. What faults it has, of which there are plenty, only add to the experience.

reviewText:
The second part of the amazing Prince of Persia trilogy. This time it's a whole lot different kind of adventure. No more fancy palace and no more romance in the air. This game tells you a different story.

Prince of Persia: Warrior Within is an excellent game that reveals its greatness as you progress. It starts off a bit run of mill with our moody hero slicing up bad guys, but things take a turn for the best when you get to the island. From here on it's a mind bending challenge after mind bending challenge - each more well thought out and engrossing than the last.

The graphics are very dark and atmospheric and the gameplay is great too. The Prince feels nice to control as he runs across walls, swings on poles and does tons of cool acrobatic tricks.

They made some huge changes to the fighting system. Now there are lots of combos and even enviormental kills. Now you can grab and throw enemies off ledges and over them.

The voice acting seems worse to me.  Especially because Yuri Lowenthal's voice is gone.

The music is very different from the first game. This time it's all rock and metal, which I didn't really like. Because I'm not a fan of such. But it was necessary. The game forces you to run away from an dark, terrifying guardian of time named Dahaka. And the music is chosen well for this part of the game.

The game looks and feels awesome. The plot is a sick sticky web that makes you think fast and act faster. New powers and weapons are always nice to see in a game. And trust me, there are a lot of weapons here. Especially because the Prince can now Dual Wield.

Lots of secret areas, just like the first game. And some awesome hidden weapons too. You'll have to stray off course in order to find them.

Prince of Persia: Warrior Within is a challenging and fun game. It requires brawn, brains and an appreciation of wicked looking island. It doesn't beat the first game, but still...



10/10
voteText: 51 of 54 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Combat and overall gameplay has been significantly improved over The Sands of Time. It makes for challenging and continuously engaging fight sequences broken up by exploring reliably beautiful environments. I can recommend Warrior Within because the combat in it's predecessor was in dire need of refinement and this game meets those needs thoroughly. However, I want to know exactly what was going through Ubisoft's collective heads when they thought changing the light hearted, funny, and romantic tone of The Sands of Time to the angry and serious tone in Warrior Within was a good idea. If you enjoyed the characterization and storytelling from the first game then you'll be sad to hear that neither of which make any sort of return in this game. However, If good combat and thrilling visuals sells it to you, then Warrior Within is certainly worth a look.

reviewText: This is my favorite Prince of Persia installment. While the creator of Prince, Jordan Mechner, might not like the dark and somewhat brutal approach to the series, me and many other Prince's fans do and there are reasons for it. The developers just did the work well. The level design is nice and entertaining and the setting in the dark castle is beautiful. Another highlight of Warrior Within is the combat system with many awesome looking and effective combos. You'll feel it when you try it.\n\nIf you're a fan of Prince or some other platforming/fighting games (like Lara Croft, for example), try the game.

reviewText:
Completed this game twice (on both endings) when I was a kid, which was ten years ago.
Re-bought now on steam, I see this game has still it's charm!

Simple & smooth movement, deep combat with combos & fancy moves, and looooong story playtime, with dark, almost sadistic atmosphere.

Even though I don't listen to metal, it really fits this game.

Graphics are OK. Animations of fire are somehow too fast, and you need to play with VSYNC on, otherwise you will have some problems due to high FPS value. BUT that's nothing major to worry about.

Difficulty - this game can be brutal for newbies. Even frustrating at certain times. But, unlike some other games, this one is highly SKILL based. It's not random - everything can be done without harm. It just depends on your skills, really.

10/10

reviewText:
The Bronze Egg of the trilogy, easily the most buggy and difficult.

It's like they had some sort of quality control crisis, because some things are noticeably crude compared to Sands of Time, like some visuals, sounds, and then theres the glitches. The glitches usually consist of sometimes buggy as hell parkouring, I.E. I go to the very edge of a beam, jump, and end up hover glitching over the end of the other beam, either barely making it, or falling to my death. Then theres some random sound glitches, well at least the glitches in general are sometimes worth a laugh.

This sequel has an incredibly emo tone, a ton of new combat moves and combos, a switchable secondary weapon which has durability and can be thrown, a bunch of new enemies, and an evil OCD demon 10 times scarier than Nemesis from Resident Evil 3 that chases you down and wants you dead. Its usually a parkour chase when you encounter him, avoid him and parkour correctly, or die horribly. He's not fond of water, so a chase usually ends past a waterfall or something similar.

Also, there are some hidden unbreakable secret secondary weapons in some areas, like a Rayman glove you can slap everything to death with? Or a flamingo that probably came from that weird TV show that was in Max Payne.

Then theres the Water Sword, a secret primary weapon you can get near the end of the game by doing some akward backtracking and whatnot (this games equivalent of the Master Sword, except optional), and also you need to have found every life upgrade to get it. It also unlocks the game's true boss/ending as well in which you smack a certain nemesis to death with said sword.

So if you liked the first game, and don't mind some hilarious glitches and incredibly annoying dog demons that explode, give this a try.

reviewText: A very fun game. The mix of parkour and combat is very well done and it feels so good to slow mo chop an enemies head off.  The story line in my opinion is pretty ok but nothing that will bring tears to your eyes because it is so great. The dark appearance and music does a good job of setting a mood of suspence and danger, as if you are being chased (which you are). There are many secrets that with some effort you can find adding a nice little alternitive than just following the main plot all the way. There are many weapons to find and because The Prince is now wielding two weapons there are some nice combos to be had. The controls are also fluent and well done. However just becasue you are fighting doesnt mean that you just hack and slash your way through, there are many interesting puzzles that add a great element to the game. The game also has decent graphics but you must remember this game is from around 2004 so it is not what you are used to in todays games. Overall this game is VERY FUN and what really does it for me is the great combat, puzzle and parkour mixture. 9/10

reviewText:
Prince Of Persia Warrior Within is a Action-Adventure Game Following where The Sands Of Time left off.The Prince is back,Gone Goth and aquired Down-Syndrome since are last Visit it Seems.The Fighting Mechanics are well done,doing what the Previous Persia lacked in,you will be able to Combo,Grab,Duel-Wield,Throw,and more,but what has always been the Essence of the Prince Of Persia,is the ability to Control Time,this is no different.You're able to Rewind,often when killed or dropped from your doom,Stop,and Fast-Forward Time.TheControls are Slightly Annoying,but you get used to them.Match these all together and what do You Get?A Fun,Enjoyable,Consiberly long Prince Of Persia Game.
Time for the Story,the Story in Warrior Within,well, Good to say the least,the Prince,after being tricked to releasing an ancient evil,is on his way to The Island Of Time to Undo his Mistake from the Last Game.

Buy:Yes

reviewText:
Warrior Within is the first sequel to Ubisoft's 2003 Sand of Time, taking place third Chronologically right after 2010's The Forgotten Sands. As I had said before SoT was an almost perfect game, with amazing story, unrivaled scenery, and perfect character arcs. Everything that lacked in that game this one improved, such as combat. However the once brown-haired insecure Daddy's boy Prince that was in the orginal is buried under a ♥♥♥♥♥♥-off emo hiding behind his black flowing hair and facial scars.

The game is not bad in any sense of the word, besides the horrible bugs that could cause you to skip ten hours of gameplay and be doomed to re-do or the most difficult battles in the series.. It's just darker and grittier, makes sense since he killed his own brother and been hunted like an animal ever since by the Dahaka.

If youre a fan of SoT it's worth the buy.

At first I would recommend this game. But having beat it now, I look back, I actually kinda maybe  ♥♥♥♥ing hated playing this game.
ok i have finished sands of time and i have played a little forgotten sands. warrior within, definitely the worst.
Its better than sands of time in the aspect that the combat has gotten a little better (still pretty similar, except you don't need to absorb people anymore cause you don't have the dagger of time).

But your overall experience is impedied by the
-unfairness of the combat (if you fall to the floor, enemies can still repeatedly hurt you making it impossible to get up).
- getting sands is much rarier in this game
- UNBELIEVABLY repeatative, like the game is pretty long already without having to go back through places 3 times for no reason. seriously Prince has the worst sense of planning, you go to one side of the castle and then have to go all the back like 3 times. and its not like an open map, these are closed rooms and hall ways. and the objective and enemies are the same. exactly the same. it gets excrutiatingly boring.
- the glitcheness, i don't think this is my computer, if it is then i retract this one. but there were times where i would be running a rope on a wall, and i would just stop and stick to the wall, having to waste a precious sand tank (seriously ♥♥♥♥♥ hard to get) to get off. other glitches happened as well, especially annoying when fighting, but it is an old game, and it didn't happen too frequently.

and im sure there are other things that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off about this game, but seriously, its late, i just finished the game and i got uni tomorrow or should i say later today. so onto the confusing things.

like any game, movie, comic, manga, book, etc. when time travel is included, plot holes are created. warrior within is pretty solid none the less.
Another confusing point, the emo'ish half/skantly/wearingnothingbutblackbraandpanties women that attack you.... is it really necessary for them to moan and scream in plessure and talk about pleasure and many sexual things as they stab you repeatedly, i mean come on, mixed signals. and they mount your back as well, and your like hell yea, but then they stab you. like way to lead the Prince on. But seriously, people in rooms next to me might get the wrong idea, i mean my porn doesn't have any pain fetish in it at all!
and it is soo out of place, like there are giant monsters and then these half naked ladies getting off on killing you. like did the empress of time when hiring these people be like... hmm yea i kinda like the giant armored monsters, lets just have 2 or 3 of these guys... but lets blow our how employment budget on these stripper demons.
maybe Prince walked into the wrong castle, he actually walked into a big ♥♥♥ brothel, i mean that would have been a great twist end.

Im gonna put this as a recommend anyway, cause the prince of persia is a good series, and i have had some fun. if there are others like me just playing through the series, you gotta get past this one anyway. the combat was pretty cool at times, cool acrobatic ♥♥♥♥.


But sands of times was better.

reviewText:
Warrior Within is a worthy sequel to the great Sands of Time. The story continues seven years after the events in the Sands of Time with the Prince of Persia as he sets out to find the Empress who created the sands... of time. His goal is to stop her and change his fate. In the first game, after stabbing the hourglass with the Dagger of Time, the Prince had released the Sands and changed the timeline. Due to this, he has been constantly hunted down by the Dahaka, an inevitable being of fate which, by killing the Prince, could correct the timeline and the Prince's fate. That is why the Prince embarks to the Island of Time to confront the Empress, to change his fate permanently.

One of the more notable aspects of Warrior Within is how violent it is. The tone is much dark than it's predecessor and even the levels are grimier. But the platforming, bar hopping, ledge jumping, wall running, etc; it's all still there. And still just as fun. But what's even more notable about this game is the element of time travel. The plot gets really interesting about 3/4ths of the way through when various mysteries are uncovered and pieces are put together by the prince. His development and keen insight were a joy to watch throughout.

One last thing, make sure you get all nine life upgrades to get the water sword for the alternate ending, which in reality is the canonical ending that continues into The Two Thrones. Plus it's so much more rewarding than the regular ending.

Anyway, great game, but my only major complaint might be the drastic changes in music, from the Middle-eastern styled orchestral to the guitar driven metal. Not a fan of the metal use in this game. Oh, and I guess more PC options would have been nice. A few bugs. No other complaints really.

9.1/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: A great instalment in the series! I think this game upped the difficulty, which was essential after the Sands of Times which was a little easy at times. However, I do think the game took a few step backs from the Sands of Time. The first being the tone, I personally felt the dark tone of the game was completely unnecessary and the game could of easily gotten away with a lighter tone. Also, I find the change of the Prince’s voice completely off-putting. I have no idea why they changed it but it was the completely wrong decision. Also, his personality was a little too extreme at times. I could not imagine the SOT calling anyone a ‘♥♥♥♥♥’. Yes, it’s meant to be years later and this and that happened. Though the developer chose to make all that happen to make him ‘dark and edgy’ in the first place, I’d rather them of not. Apart from those issues the rest of the game was extremely strong and built upon the gameplay I loved from the Sands of Time.\n

reviewText:
I must start by saying Warrior Within is my least favorite of the trilogy. I played the entire series back in the day and recently purchased them again while they were on sale. The graphics are obviously dated but what do you expect it's and old game, the problem lies with the rest of the game.  The soundtrack in my opinnion doesn't really do anything besides prevent awkward silence (which there is still a lot of) and personally I don't think the music really fits the game. The gameplay is alright, the game itself can be enjoyable but the plot isn't really that great compaired to the other games.

The major problem with the plot is that if you jump from the first game Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time to this you won't really know what's going on, from my understanding this game continues off of a side game created for the ds. That's a pretty bad idea in my oppinion, but after a short while you understand what's going on but will most likely wish there was some more detail on what happened inbetween the two games. But I do give the game a little bit of props for having a little replayability by having an alternative ending. The alternative ending is what leads to the beginning of The Two Thrones so I do reccomend getting all the life upgrades.

The game suffers through a few annoyences, for example throughout the playthrough you will probably notice that they try and make the game seem badass in every aspect.  Notably music by Godsmack, and a first boss featuring armour that hardly protects her buttcrack. Honestly I think most of the things they put in the game to try and make it cool" just took away from the overall gameplay. But what can I say at least the combat was fun and I always like climbing things
date: so although it's very far from perfect I reccomend this game but only if you play through the Sand of Time. And if you enjoy the Sands of Time and think this is to stupid so you don't want to try the Two Thrones I will say you should change your oppinion as the Two Thrones is a TON better than this one."

reviewText:
What an unbelievable game. One of the greatest of all time.

The story is really nice, it keeps a strong connection with the first one, while it can run as a stand-alone story. Really thrilling and original.

The graphics and the atmosphere made a radical change here. From the charming arab palaces of the first game, we will be now in a cursed island, where everything will try to kill us. We will have to fight using the hundres of combo to get rid of the hordes of monster that will follow us, explore downhearted scenarios and try to survive. The castle is just badass, and the atmosphere is really depressive and sadistic.

The music is totally awesome. Heavy metal during the fights, depressive dark ambient during the puzzles and exploration stages.

Also, the game is ultra gore and violent. Be ready to decapitate and cut in two pieces your enemies, using hundreds of different weapons and combos.

A masterpiece. I know some fans were upset because of the radical change from the first game, but really, this game is nuts. Black metal made game.

No bugs reported on this version, just some people, like it happened to me, will have this file corrupted: Video\Cine\CINE0102.BIK (inside the folder where the game is installed), that makes the game crash after the very first boss battle. The only way to make the game not crash is to replace this file with its uncorrupted version you can find in cd/dvd version of the game, or you can just download it, as legally as you can, from internet.

reviewText:
Finished it. The favourite part, it is like eigth or tenth walkthrough.

There is no point dividing the judgement into 2004 point of view and 2015. Everything (both + and - ) is actually the same.

The gameplay became much more diverse - more aggressive, different approaches, swords that really make a difference, a lot of secondary weapons to choose from. Definitely the exact improvement needed.

Change in past-present was as satisfying as ever - cannot recall any other game at that time with such concept.

The plot is twisted, providing unexpected turns and decisions. At least it was confusing 10 years ago for a 11-year boy.
A lot of different bosses, each recquiring a different approach - by far, the greatest addition since the previous game.

You can play the game even if you didn't finish the SOT part. Still rewarding.

reviewText: I used to love this game so much, but unfortunately, I can't recommend it to anyone with a current system for gaming. It's just so infuriatingly glitchy, that you constantly keep dying because the character falls through the map, grabs the air a half meter away from the ledge then falls, etc.\nHowever, the level design, the fights and the atmosphere are so masterfully created that you might be able to live with its many technical shortcomings. For me, the real dealbreaker was the presence of many game-breaking bugs. Basically, these glitches prevented me from proceeding in any direction so after some time I had to quit playing. It's a real shame though, because this was an amazing game in its time.

reviewText:
As much as I try to love this game, it is so full of bugs that I've spent more time being angered/frustrated by glitches than actually having fun.

Seems like it was pronounced complete as soon as 1 game tester managed to successfully completed it. By shere luck, it seems. They knew it and released it anyway.

I love the dark setting, Godsmack inspired soundtrack, the cheap but effective idea of playing same level in 2 different timelines. Even the extremely cheesy dialogue.

But after spending past 2 hours trying to climb down a simple wall in Tower Activation (past), I've had just about enough. I wish I could get a refund but alas, I've spent too much in-game time already.

This makes me sad as, game-breaking bugs/glitches aside, this would easily be my favorite installment of PoP. But the release was rushed before sufficient playtesting, and apparently no effort was made to fix any bugs after the game was released.

reviewText:
This is a nasty, boneheaded sequel to a great classic game and its sins are many.  For one, it emphasizes combat far more than the first game while utilizing a fighting system that is more busted than ever; this time the Prince flails around like a stoned acrobat who also happens to be a dead swan, flopping his lanky limbs at everything BUT that which you intend.

The combat is not the greatest offender, however.  That honor goes to the level design!  Whereas in the first game you joyfully somersaulted once through each well-designed obstacle course before assailing the next unique level, Warrior sees you slogging repeatedly through the same murky, uninspired switch and saw and pole courses, interminably back and forth, back and forth, until either your sanity departs or you do a rage uninstall, which is what I SHOULD have done.

And for the crap-flavored icing on the carrion cake, the tone has shifted from cool and easy Arabian Nights-style to grunty grimdark BS.  No longer is the Prince a tough yet somewhat sensitive sort (which jived with his incredible acrobatic ability); now he's just some turd with tribal tats who gruffly tells everyone and everything, including ****ing bats, that he will bloodily DESTROY any and all who stand in the way of his legendary sword arm!  Uhhgh!

This is garbage, this is trash, this is a poopy old relic that deserves to stay buried forever.  Why did I bother to play through this endless torturefest, acquiring all the life upgrades and getting the good" ending no less?  Chock it up to a bout of extreme self-loathing.  But never again
date: never again will I waste life and time on something so worthless as this . . . so perhaps I learned something from the experience."

reviewText: All charm and wit of Sands of Time were gutted living a disgusting shell that lost track of what made its predecessor good.\n\nTerrible camera, unresponsive controls, a refocusing on combat, a puerile shift to a darker grittier story including immature reduction of the female supporting characters to wearing oversexualized butt-floss outfits (thankfully they removed the fun and witty Farah rather than make her terrible) and a replacement of the middle-eastern music with lame metal. A more open world gameplay rather than making things fun leaves you going over the same bland hard to see jumps over and over as you go in circles thinking you are making forward progress. Also included are many terrible timed sections that compound controller and camera issues to make it a terrible experience.

reviewText:
For the first few hours, the game is a tad alienating. Everyone mocks it for the drastic change in tone and the downright bipolar change in the Prince's character. However, once the game gets going, it's very enjoyable. At many points, I found it to be a worthy sequel to Sands of Time.

And then the endgame hits.

There will be no spoilers, but to those familiar with the structure of storytelling, around the end of the second act, the game design completely soils itself. Glitches are abundant. The controls become even more clunky, and the plot makes even less sense.

Sands of Time's narrative might have been overly simplistic, but at least it was consistent. This game is a glitch-riddled, rushed mess.

reviewText: Very good game. I remember playing this on my Gamecube back then. There are a tiny bit more bugs in the pc version then I thought, but they don't ruin the game. It is still one of my favorite game in the series!\nThe Parcour in this game never gets repetitive, as well as the Boss fights and Dahaka chases.\nWhat makes this game different are the secrets that you don't see on the first time. And when you find a secret you are like: Damn

Please ignore the low playtime. I own this game for the Playstation 2, & from what I've seen, this version is reletively unchanged.

So yeah. 2nd game in the prince of persia trilogy, & considered the worst of the 3 for being buggy, having the game being more combat focused, & turning prince into a gruff ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. But, I like these changes. I like the darker tone, I prefer the game being more focused on combat, & I like princes new personality.

Story: 7/10

The first game had you trying to undo what the prince did: Opening the sands of time with the dagger of time. In this game: the prince is being chased by the unstoppable guardian of time: The Dahaka. The prince is being chased by this creature, because when he opened the sands, he should've died, he however, did not. Because of this, he has disrupted the timeline & must be killed to restore it. The princes job is to somehow change his fate. Okay, pretty interesting. Its not 10/10 5 STARZ, but its not too shabby.

Music: 9/10

HOLLY SHEET METUL!! Most of this games soundtrack is heavy metal, which I really like! It fits this games darker tone, & they all sound fantastic. The main song of the game is I stand alone" by Godsmack. an instrumental version of the song plays during certain parts of the game

reviewText: After saving the world from the Time, Our brave hero, the dashing Prince took a dive. He started experimenting, went a bit to the darker side (not shade, but to actual darkers), got some tatoos and traded the dagger for a much cooler sword. All this ended after a demon of Time named Dahaka decided enaugh is enaugh and went to straghten the Prince of Persia. Somewhere along the Empress of Time joined in on the fun and so the Chaos was born.

reviewText: This game is often treated like the worthless middle child of the last gen POP games, while it lacked the feel and the better story of Sands of time, it improved on a lot from Sands such as the combat system which was mediocre in Sands but alot better in Warrior within, just the whole darker theme didn't really fit the game. Still if you like POP this is a great title if you can get passed the lack luster storyline.

reviewText: UGH I had to restart the entire game after I progressed 3/4 into it. Becareful about getting all the life upgrades even though it may give you a better ending with a new boss, you might glitch the game out if you don't get the upgrades in the correct order. Still....the game is a huge improvement over the first. Story is pretty meh but combat, parkour, and puzzles have been improved. Worth checking out.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Prince of Persia: Warrior Within is more mature in theme and the Prince himself. The game improve with free-form combat and story, with the help from Hollywood script writer. Sands of Time universe is expanded with more mystical and to a larger scale. The plot twist is so cool and memorable. Combat is faster, more brutal and more satisfying. Dahaka chase sequences are always thrilling. This is a worth sequel fits for the noble Prince and this beloved series.

My main gripes:

date: much less getting knocked down and not being able to get up again. That being said
recommended: fighting multiple opponents can still often be extremely tricky. Single opponents
voteText: are fodder.\n- The bloody camera. I think this is the one thing that caused me the most deaths in this game. It's very difficult to control and does what it wants sometimes
votesHelpful: despite it not being enabled.\n- Controls are muddy again
votesTotal: the Prince is often not doing what you want him to do. For example
votesFunny: I used a 360 Pad and bound the time button to the left trigger. Well
column16: that button does not work for the combat time skills
column17: instead I had to rebind the key to another one (left shoulder). Figuring this out was a pain. Another example: Changing direction on a swing pole is left to chance it seems as the Prince sometimes turns and sometimes not. Gladly there are almost no time sensitive jumps in this fashion. You also still need to hold down the action button for all those things to work. Another example: Holding down the direction button to move the Prince forwards does not always result in him going forward
column18: because the game takes the bloody camera angle into account
column19: so instead of just pushing forward on the stick to move a rotating lever
column20: you have to also rotate your stick to move it...*sigh*\n\nAnd my main gripe with the game: The god damn back tracking. I needed 15 hours on easy with a guide to complete this one
column21: I visited some areas 3 or 4 times due to story reasons. You'd better memorize all the areas (in the past and present zones nonetheless) or use a guide. I shudder taking a break for a week or a month from this
column22: coming back and realizing that I have no clue whatsoever where to go and how to get there. The game is an enigma. While it does have a "map"
column24: as it's just an "overworld map" and offers NO details whatsoever. Infuriating.\n\nAnother gripe: The last portion of the game is
column27: but also extremely trivial. There is almost no way to fail at that stage and combat becomes extremely simplistic.\n\nWhat does it do well then? Well

reviewText: Warrior Within is one of my favorite games. Yes, this game is much darker and bloodier than the SoT and TT, but come on, prince tries to save himself from the time guardian Dahaka, and since the environment is dark and filled with dangerous monsters, prince has to adapt to it, in order to survive. And the soundtrack written by the Godsmack makes everything to fill your journey with the right mood.
